input.content: Use <image1> as the opening card and the narration in <audio1> as the voiceover to continue the lesson about thyroid health—moving from lab numbers to tissue function, common pitfalls, Hashimoto’s, iodine, stress, and practical fixes. Please return exactly one video and one audio in the output as supporting material.

output.content: <video1> animates the flow from the hypothalamus–pituitary–thyroid axis to tissue-level conversion, contrasts TSH-only screening with a fuller panel, and illustrates iodine/goiter, halogen exposure, stress–cortisol effects, and Hashimoto’s. The single narration in <audio2> guides viewers through these scenes and lands on clear actions—targeted testing, nutrient repletion, stress management, cleaner water, and gut–liver support—to help resolve thyroid symptoms rather than masking them.

input.content: Use <image1> as the opening frame and the narration in <audio1> as the setup, then continue the story into a short explainer that contrasts felt agency with brain mechanisms (sleepwalking, anesthesia, split-brain experiments, social emotion, creativity). Return exactly one video and one audio in the output as supporting material.

output.content: <video1> opens on the translucent brain from the title card, then moves through five scenes: a sleep lab showing complex actions during partial arousal; EEG spectrograms under anesthesia as consciousness fades and returns; split-brain tasks where each hemisphere acts on different information; social-decision trials revealing the pull of guilt and cooperation; and an fMRI-style visualization of freestyle creativity as self-monitoring quiets. The single narration in <audio2> connects these vignettes, concluding that awareness is only part of the story and that recognizing unconscious influences can improve self-understanding and choice.

input.content: Use <image1> as the opening card and the narration in <audio1> to kick off a kid-friendly explainer about plant parts, photosynthesis, adaptations, pollination, fertilization, and germination. Return one video and one audio in the output as supporting materials.

output.content: <video1> starts with the cheerful plant mascot from <image1>, then moves through short animated scenes: leaves cooking with sunlight, roots sipping water, desert and rainforest adaptations, a flower showing pollen transfer, and a seed sprouting into a seedling. The single narration in <audio2> guides children through each step, tying the parts and processes together and ending with a reminder that caring for plants helps our whole planet.

input.content: Use <image1> as the opener and the narration in <audio1> to kick off an explainer that shows: lipid-packaged mRNA entering cells, translation into spike pieces, antigen presentation, antibody formation, and memory. Please return exactly one video and one audio in the output as the supporting materials.

output.content: <video1> animates the full sequence—from injection and cellular uptake of the lipid nanoparticle to spike production, antigen display, and neutralizing antibodies locking onto viral spikes—ending with memory cell icons. The single narration in <audio2> ties the steps together and reiterates the key points: temporary mRNA instructions, no DNA alteration, and rapid, targeted immunity on exposure.

input.content: Use <image1> to open and <audio1> as the narration scaffold, then continue with simple animations of a joint cross-section showing synovial fluid, bubble formation and collapse, a tendon snap comparison, the ~20-minute refractory period, and a brief note on long-term safety. Please return exactly one video and one audio in the output as the supporting materials.

output.content: <video1> transitions from the hands to a labeled joint diagram: the capsule fills with synovial fluid, the cavity expands, a bubble flashes and collapses with a pop, then a sidebar shows a tendon flicking over bone to contrast sounds. A timer icon illustrates the ~20-minute wait before the same knuckle can pop again, followed by a lighthearted nod to the 60-year one-hand experiment and a caution card about possible swelling/grip strength if overdone. The single narration in <audio2> ties these visuals together and ends with a commonsense takeaway: painless cracking is usually fine—just be considerate of others.

input.content: Use <image1> as the opening frame and the narration in <audio1> to set up a short explainer on viral entry—receptor binding, fusion/endocytosis, genome release, replication, and spread. Please provide exactly one video and one audio in the output as supporting materials.

output.content: <video1> follows the virus from cilia-lined airway to receptor binding, shows lock-and-key attachment, membrane fusion/endocytosis, uncoating of the genome, replication and assembly, and release of progeny. The single narration in <audio2> walks through each step and closes with the idea that therapies aim to interrupt entry to stop infection at the source.

input.content: Begin with <image1> as the opener and use the narration in <audio1> to set up how normal pancreatic cells lose growth control and form a tumor. Please return exactly one video and one audio in the output to support the explanation.

output.content: <video1> zooms from a healthy pancreatic field into a single cell acquiring mutations, shows unchecked divisions forming a mass, compression of nearby tissue, recruitment of blood vessels, and a few cells escaping toward vessels. The single narration in <audio2> walks through these stages and underscores why early detection and DNA-repair–targeted therapies matter.

input.content: Use <image1> as the opening frame and narrate with <audio1> to introduce what a CT scan is, how to prepare, what sensations to expect, and when results arrive. Please include exactly one video and one audio in the output as supporting material.

output.content: <video1> walks the viewer through the CT experience: check-in and prep, drinking/IV contrast, moving onto the table, the scanner’s noises and brief breath-holds, and a calm outro explaining the timeline for results. The single narration in <audio2> matches the visuals and reassures patients about the temporary warmth/metallic taste, the short imaging time, and the purpose of the scan.

input.content: Use <image1> as the opener and the narration in <audio1> to introduce why a student chose UQ Biomedical Science—facilities, research access, community, and career pathways. Please include exactly one video and one audio in the output as supporting material.

output.content: <video1> moves from the student interview to a quick tour of UQ’s biomed spaces—wet labs, anatomy models, imaging rooms, and a research floor—then shows scenes of student societies and mentoring sessions. The single narration in <audio2> ties these moments together, emphasizing modern facilities, early research involvement, supportive campus life, and how the program opens doors to medicine, research, and biotech.

input.content: Build a short explainer that continues from <image1> and the narration in <audio1>, showing why mixing substances is risky and how reactions vary from use to use. Please return exactly one video and one audio in the output as supporting material.

output.content: <video1> animates the meeting of two substances, then transitions to simple organ icons (heart, lungs, brain) pulsing erratically to illustrate additive and masking effects (depressant + depressant; stimulant + depressant; medication interactions). A final card lists clear warning signs of overdose and the emergency call prompt. The single narration in <audio2> ties the scenes together: reactions vary by dose, timing, and individual biology; mixing increases risk of respiratory failure and cardiac stress; the safest approach is not to combine drugs; seek medical help immediately if danger signs appear.
